title: 103_hr2662
content:
The "Business Improvement Act of 1993" establishes business activity targets for small businesses and procurement procedures. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration must consider contracts awarded to program participants before the enactment of the Act as contracts awarded for attainment of business activity targets. The Small Business Act is amended to allow participating agencies to enter into contracts with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals using restricted competition or a price preference. The authority granted will be in effect until September 30, 2000. Eligibility of past development program participants for Section 8(a) contract awards is also addressed. The Small Business Act is amended to allow agencies to contract with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals using restricted competition or a price preference until September 30, 2000. Eligibility for Section 8(a) contract awards for past development program participants is also addressed, including criteria for competitive and sole source awards. SEC. 5 amends Section 8(a)(1) of the Small Business Act by eliminating competitive contracts under subparagraph (D). SEC. 6 ensures continued access to business opportunities. Section 8(a)(3) of the Small Business Act is amended to require competitive bidding for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if certain conditions are met. This includes having offers from at least 2 eligible small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals, performing similar contracts under the same program, and the current contractor graduating from a development program before the solicitation is issued. The Small Business Act now requires competitive bidding for contracts with participating agencies, with restrictions on awarding contracts to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals who have graduated from a development program. The small business must agree to subcontract a portion of the contract to other small businesses in the developmental stage of the program. The Small Business Act mandates competitive bidding for contracts with participating agencies, limiting awards to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals who have completed a development program. These businesses must subcontract a portion of the contract to other small businesses in the developmental stage of the program, with specific requirements for follow-on contracts. SEC. 7. STUDY OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PARTICIPATION TERMS BY INDUSTRY SECTOR; SUSPENSION OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GRADUATIONS. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize a short-term study on program participation terms by industry sector for small businesses. Additionally, the suspension of development program graduations is extended for small businesses participating in certain programs or activities. The Small Business Act is amended to allow continued participation in programs or activities until final regulations are issued based on a study, or until eligibility expires as per requirements. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE WITH BUY INDIAN ACT.

Federal agencies contracting with the Small Business Administration under section 8(a) of the Small Business Act for goods or services from economically disadvantaged Indian tribes are considered compliant with the Buy Indian Act.

SEC. 9. UNIFORM PROCEDURES FOR CONTESTING STATUS OF CONCERNS.

The Administrator, in collaboration with participating agencies, will establish uniform procedures within 120 days for contesting the status of a small business concern owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals.
